query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Poscia che l’accoglienze oneste e liete 2 furo iterate tre e quattro volte, 3 Sordel si trasse, e disse: «Voi, chi siete?».
query.result:
**English:**
1 After the kind and joyful greetings 2 had been repeated three and four times, 3 Sordello stepped forward and said: "Who are you?".
**Cornish:**
1 Wosa an kovlennys onest ha lowen 2 veu reyteratys tri ha peswar gweyth, 3 Sordel a waytas ha leverel: "Pyth yw'gas?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
4 «Anzi che a questo monte fosser volte 5 l’anime degne di salire a Dio, 6 fur l’ossa mie per Ottavian sepolte.
query.result:
**English:**
4 "Rather than to this mountain were turned 5 the souls worthy of ascending to God, 6 my bones were buried by Octavian.
**Cornish:**
4 "Yn lemmyn nag an menydh ma 5 ene an eneow teg dhe vos dhe Dhew, 6 ow kledhys veu gans Octavian.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
7 Io son Virgilio; e per null’ altro rio 8 lo ciel perdei che per non aver fé». 9 Così rispuose allora il duca mio.
query.result:
**English:**
7 "I am Virgil; and for no other sin 8 did I lose heaven than for not having faith." 9 Thus replied then my leader.
**Cornish:**
7 "My a'n Virgili; ha na neb traow arall 8 y'm golli an nef avel gen fe." 9 Henwynna an gwella an lemmyn vy.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Qual è colui che cosa innanzi sé 11 sùbita vede ond’ e’ si maraviglia, 12 che crede e non, dicendo «Ella è . . . non è . . . »,
13 tal parve quelli; e poi chinò le ciglia, 14 e umilmente ritornò ver’ lui, 15 e abbracciòl là ’ve ’l minor s’appiglia.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Like one who sees something before him 11 suddenly, at which he marvels, 12 who believes and does not, saying "It is . . . it is not . . . ",
13 such he seemed; and then he lowered his brows, 14 and humbly returned toward him, 15 and embraced him where the lesser one clings.
**Cornish:**
10 Kepar ha neb a wel traow rag orth 11 yn tas, hag ev a wra vyth marrek, 12 hag a grys ha na grys, leverel "Yth yw . . . nyns yw . . . ",
13 keth yw ev; ha wosa henna y'n omwiskas y'n sourcils, 14 hag yn omble dh'y dhro dhe'n keth, 15 hag y'n omglewas lemmyn may hyns a wra y'n omglewas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 «O gloria di Latin», disse, «per cui 17 mostrò ciò che potea la lingua nostra, 18 o pregio etterno del loco ond’ io fui,
19 qual merito o qual grazia mi ti mostra? 20 S’io son d’udir le tue parole degno, 21 dimmi se vien d’inferno, e di qual chiostra».
query.result:
**English:**
16 "O glory of the Latins," he said, "through whom 17 our language showed what it could do, 18 O eternal honor of the place from which I came,
19 what merit or what grace shows you to me? 20 If I am worthy to hear your words, 21 tell me if you come from hell, and from which circle."
**Cornish:**
16 "O glôr an Latin," leverel, "dreus a wrug 17 diskwedhes an peth a alla an yeth ni, 18 O prîs byth an le may hyns i a dheuth,
19 pyth meritas po pyth ras a'm diskwedh dhym? 20 Mar ow tyn dhe glewes an geuryow, 21 lever dhym a dheuth dhyworth ifern, ha dhyworth pyth chist."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 «Per tutt’ i cerchi del dolente regno», 23 rispuose lui, «son io di qua venuto; 24 virtù del ciel mi mosse, e con lei vegno.
query.result:
**English:**
22 "Through all the circles of the sorrowful kingdom," 23 he replied to him, "I have come from there; 24 the power of heaven moved me, and with it I come.
**Cornish:**
22 "A-dreus oll chist an gwlas dolurus," 23 y'n dallethas dhe'n ev, "y'm deuth hy, 24 nerth an nef a'm movas, ha gans an hanow henna y'm deuth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 Non per far, ma per non fare ho perduto 26 a veder l’alto Sol che tu disiri 27 e che fu tardi per me conosciuto.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Not for doing, but for not doing have I lost 26 the sight of the high Sun that you desire 27 and that was recognized by me too late.
**Cornish:**
25 Nyns rag ober, mes rag na ober y'm kollet 26 dhe weles an Haul ughel henna a wra'th ow synsi 27 ha henna a veu aswonnys gansan vy dhe dhewedh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Luogo è là giù non tristo di martìri, 29 ma di tenebre solo, ove i lamenti 30 non suonan come guai, ma son sospiri.
query.result:
**English:**
28 There is a place down there, not sad with torments, 29 but of darkness only, where the lamentations 30 do not sound like wails, but are sighs.
**Cornish:**
28 Le may hyns allá nebes trist gans martíri, 29 mes a dhewythow hep, may an gwelasow 30 nyns yw klevys kepar gwásow, mes ynsow sospirow.

**English:**
31 Here I stand with the innocent children 32 bitten by the teeth of death before 33 they were tainted by human sin;
34 here I stand with those who did not clothe themselves with the three holy 35 virtues, and without vice 36 knew the others and followed all of them.
**Cornish:**
31 Ama y'm eus gans an vughes nowydh 32 a veu kigrys gans dhensow an angow 33 kyns o veyn beudhys gans an pechod a dus.
34 Ama y'm eus gans an re beu na wiska 35 an teyr vrás vertudh, ha heb vyth 36 aswonnys an re erel ha'n oll dhew selwel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Ma se tu sai e puoi, alcuno indizio 38 dà noi per che venir possiam più tosto 39 là dove purgatorio ha dritto inizio».
query.result:
**English:**
37 But if you know and are able, give us some indication 38 so that we can come more quickly 39 to where Purgatory rightly begins."
**Cornish:**
37 Mes mar ow tys ha gallos, ro dhyn ni nebes merk 38 dhyn dhym rag may gallos ni dheutha moyha 39 dhe'n le may purgatory a wra y'n dalleth gwir."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Ma vedi già come dichina il giorno, 44 e andar sù di notte non si puote; 45 però è buon pensar di bel soggiorno.
query.result:
**English:**
43 But see how the day declines, 44 and it is not possible to go up at night; 45 therefore it is good to think of a pleasant resting place.
**Cornish:**
43 Mes gwel a-lemmyn pyw'th onan an jorna, 44 ha mos possybyl onan dhe ves ow kul; 45 rag tas da yw da dhybri orth plas plesans.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 Anime sono a destra qua remote; 47 se mi consenti, io ti merrò ad esse, 48 e non sanza diletto ti fier note».
query.result:
**English:**
46 Souls are here to the right, set apart; 47 if you consent, I will lead you to them, 48 and they will not fail to delight you».
**Cornish:**
46 Eneves yw y'n keffrys, set apart; 47 mar kynsenty, vy a'm gorra orth aga, 48 ha na veth heb delyth dhe'gas notys».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 «Com’ è ciò?», fu risposto. «Chi volesse 50 salir di notte, fora elli impedito 51 d’altrui, o non sarria ché non potesse?».
query.result:
**English:**
49 «How is that?», was the reply. «Who would wish 50 to climb at night, would he be prevented 51 by others, or would he not be able to?».
**Cornish:**
49 «Pyw yw henna?», o veu an golwas. «Piv a vynna 50 dhe dhrehedhi orth y'n nos, a veu efan 51 gans agan pobel, po dhe'gas na alla?».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 E ’l buon Sordello in terra fregò ’l dito, 53 dicendo: «Vedi? sola questa riga 54 non varcheresti dopo ’l sol partito:
55 non però ch’altra cosa desse briga, 56 che la notturna tenebra, ad ir suso; 57 quella col nonpoder la voglia intriga.
query.result:
**English:**
52 And the good Sordello rubbed his finger on the ground, 53 saying: «See? You would not cross this line alone 54 after the sun has set:
55 not because anything else would hinder you, 56 except the darkness of the night, from going up; 57 that, with its powerlessness, entangles the will.
**Cornish:**
52 Ha'n Sordello da yn bys vynsa y vynwes, 53 ow leverel: «Gweles? An linenn-ma 54 na wra veth orth wosa'n Howl demedhys:
55 Mes na drefen tra voos a wra dhe'gas let, 56 mes an tywyllder nos, dhe dhrehedhi orth; 57 henna, gans y anvos, a wra dhe'gas let».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Ben si poria con lei tornare in giuso 59 e passeggiar la costa intorno errando, 60 mentre che l’orizzonte il dì tien chiuso».
query.result:
**English:**
58 You could indeed return down with her 59 and wander around the coast, 60 while the horizon keeps the day enclosed.
**Cornish:**
58 Mes ty a alla gans anji dhe'gas orth 59 ha kerdhes an arvorow a-dro dhe'gas, 60 bys dhe'n Howl a wra'n jynn an jorna clos».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Allora il mio segnor, quasi ammirando, 62 «Menane», disse, «dunque là ’ve dici 63 ch’aver si può diletto dimorando».
query.result:
**English:**
61 Then my lord, as if in wonder, 62 said: «Lead me, then, to where you say 63 one can find delightful dwelling».
**Cornish:**
61 An lavarta, an Arloedh, avel mar ow admir, 62 «Menena», a leverel, «rag dhe'n le, 63 le mayth yw dhe'gas plas plesans dhe vy».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Poco allungati c’eravam di lici, 65 quand’ io m’accorsi che ’l monte era scemo, 66 a guisa che i vallon li sceman quici.
query.result:
**English:**
64 We had gone a short distance from there, 65 when I noticed that the mountain was cut off, 66 just as the valleys cut them off here.
**Cornish:**
64 Nyns o ni a veu pell owth an le, 65 pan wrugav vy dhe'n menydh o veu skevys, 66 kepar ha'n glynnow a wra'n ow skevys ama.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 «Colà», disse quell’ ombra, «n’anderemo 68 dove la costa face di sé grembo; 69 e là il novo giorno attenderemo».
query.result:
**English:**
67 «Over there», said that shade, «we will go 68 where the hillside makes a lap of itself; 69 and there we will await the new day».
**Cornish:**
67 «Dhe'n le», an leverel an avellan, «ni a wra 68 le mayth yw an menydh ow fakya y gremb; 69 ha'n le ni a wra'n ow lettya an jorna nowydh».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Tra erto e piano era un sentiero schembo, 71 che ne condusse in fianco de la lacca, 72 là dove più ch’a mezzo muore il lembo.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Between the steep and the level was a winding path, 71 which led us to the side of the hollow, 72 where the slope dies away more than halfway down.
**Cornish:**
70 Ynter ergh ha plan o veu sentiero skevys, 71 owth a'n gorra orth dhe'n tu a'n lakk, 72 le mayth yw moy es dhe'n kres an lebm a verw.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 Oro e argento fine, cocco e biacca, 74 indaco, legno lucido e sereno, 75 fresco smeraldo in l’ora che si fiacca,
76 da l’erba e da li fior, dentr’ a quel seno 77 posti, ciascun saria di color vinto, 78 come dal suo maggiore è vinto il meno.
query.result:
**English:**
73 Gold and fine silver, cochineal and white lead, 74 indigo, polished and clear wood, 75 fresh emerald at the hour it is broken,
76 placed by the grass and the flowers, within that hollow, 77 would each be defeated in colour, 78 just as the lesser is defeated by its greater.
**Cornish:**
73 Our ha arghans fyn, kok ha byak, 74 endygo, prenn kler ha seryn, 75 smerald fres yn eur pan vo dhe'n fak,
76 ow posys gans an erow ha'n bleujyow, a-ves dhe'n sen, 77 pub onan a veu gorrys yn liw, 78 kepar ha'n lyha veu gorrys gans an moy.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 Non avea pur natura ivi dipinto, 80 ma di soavità di mille odori 81 vi facea uno incognito e indistinto.
query.result:
**English:**
79 Nature alone had not painted there, 80 but with the sweetness of a thousand scents 81 it made there an unknown and indistinct [place].
**Cornish:**
79 Nyns oedh natur ow henna dhywris, 80 mes gans soavitas a vil odori 81 ow holla unn anvos ha bos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 ‘Salve, Regina’ in sul verde e ’n su’ fiori 83 quindi seder cantando anime vidi, 84 che per la valle non parean di fuori.
query.result:
**English:**
82 ‘Hail, Queen’ on the green grass and on the flowers 83 I saw souls sitting there singing, 84 who did not seem to be outside, in the valley.
**Cornish:**
82 ‘Salve, Regina’ war an gles ha’n bleujow 83 ena sedhes kanas eneval, 84 nyns eusons y’n mes an dowr a-ves.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 «Prima che ’l poco sole omai s’annidi», 86 cominciò ’l Mantoan che ci avea vòlti, 87 «tra color non vogliate ch’io vi guidi.
query.result:
**English:**
85 “Before the little sun sets,” 86 began the Mantuan who had turned us, 87 “do not ask me to guide you among those people.
**Cornish:**
85 “Myns na’n byghan howl ow tos orth,” 86 a dhallathas an Mantoan ow tos o tressa, 87 “na vynnowgh why dhe’m gorragh dheuch an dus.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Di questo balzo meglio li atti e ’ volti 89 conoscerete voi di tutti quanti, 90 che ne la lama giù tra essi accolti.
query.result:
**English:**
88 From this ridge you will be able to know better 89 the actions and faces of all of them, 90 than if you were down in the valley among them.
**Cornish:**
88 A-dhia an bal ma’th ow tos gorragh an gwriow 89 ha’n boos oll an dus, 90 ages yn-mes an dowr ow tos orth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Colui che più siede alto e fa sembianti 92 d’aver negletto ciò che far dovea, 93 e che non move bocca a li altrui canti,
94 Rodolfo imperador fu, che potea 95 sanar le piaghe c’hanno Italia morta, 96 sì che tardi per altri si ricrea.
query.result:
**English:**
91 He who sits highest and seems 92 to have neglected what he should have done, 93 and who does not move his lips to the others’ songs,
94 was Emperor Rudolf, who could have 95 healed the wounds that have killed Italy, 96 so that it is too late for anyone else to revive it.
**Cornish:**
91 An hini a-sedh ughella ha’n gwriow 92 a-wra dhegorri an peth a dhalleth oberi, 93 ha nyns movia y geyn dhe’n canow erel,
94 o Rudolf an emperour, a alleth gallos 95 dhe wella an clevesow a-wra Italia marow, 96 marow bys vyth dhe neb aral dhe wella.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 L’altro che ne la vista lui conforta, 98 resse la terra dove l’acqua nasce 99 che Molta in Albia, e Albia in mar ne porta:
100 Ottacchero ebbe nome, e ne le fasce 101 fu meglio assai che Vincislao suo figlio 102 barbuto, cui lussuria e ozio pasce.
query.result:
**English:**
97 The other who comforts him with his gaze, 98 ruled the land where the water rises 99 that the Moldau carries into the Elbe, and the Elbe into the sea:
100 his name was Ottokar, and in his swaddling clothes 101 he was much better than his son Wenceslas, 102 the bearded one, whom luxury and idleness feed.
**Cornish:**
97 An aral a-wra y’n golwg ow confortya, 98 a ressa an tir le may an dowr a-dhia, 99 an dowr a-wra Molta dhe’n Albia, ha’n Albia dhe’n mor:
100 Ottacchero oedh y hanow, ha’n y fasow 101 oedh gwella moy ages y vab Vincislao 102 an barvek, neb lussuria ha ozio a-vos.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 E quel nasetto che stretto a consiglio 104 par con colui c’ha sì benigno aspetto, 105 morì fuggendo e disfiorando il giglio:
106 guardate là come si batte il petto! 107 L’altro vedete c’ha fatto a la guancia 108 de la sua palma, sospirando, letto.
query.result:
**English:**
103 And that little nose who seems to be in council 104 with the one who has such a kind face, 105 died fleeing and deflowering the lily:
106 look there how he beats his breast! 107 See the other one who has made a bed of his palm 108 for his cheek, sighing.
**Cornish:**
103 Ha henna neseth byghan a-wra yn-mes an kevri 104 gans an hini a-wra golwg mar dhyner, 105 a verwis ow tos orth ha’n lili a-dhystori:
106 gwelowgh ena le may a-wra y geyn a-skei! 107 Gwelowgh an aral a-wra dhe’n wonn a-oberi 108 a-dhia y balm, ow tos orth ha’n golwg mar dhyner.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Padre e suocero son del mal di Francia: 110 sanno la vita sua viziata e lorda, 111 e quindi viene il duol che sì li lancia.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Father and father-in-law are of the evil of France: 110 they know his corrupt and filthy life, 111 and from that comes the grief that so pierces them.
**Cornish:**
109 Tas ha’n tas-yn-le a-wra a’n drok a Franki: 110 ymons y vyw y vyth a-wra corupt ha lor, 111 ha dhia henna a-dhia an dowr a-wra y skei.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 Rade volte risurge per li rami 122 l’umana probitate; e questo vole 123 quei che la dà, perché da lui si chiami.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Human goodness rarely rises again through the branches; 122 and this is what he who gives it wants, 123 so that people will call on him.
**Cornish:**
121 Radegva re a-surj dhe’n kevri a-dhia an skorennow 122 an probitas a dus; ha henna a-vynn 123 an hini a-wra y, rag dhe vos leverel y hanow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Anche al nasuto vanno mie parole 125 non men ch’a l’altro, Pier, che con lui canta, 126 onde Puglia e Proenza già si dole.
query.result:
**English:**
124 My words also go to Nasuto, 125 no less than to the other, Pier, who sings with him, 126 because of whom Apulia and Provence now grieve.
**Cornish:**
124 Yma'gan Nasuto vy henna ger 125 nag vy dhe'n Pier, neb ow kanas ganso, 126 rag a wra Apulia ha Proens ow dol.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Tant’ è del seme suo minor la pianta, 128 quanto, più che Beatrice e Margherita, 129 Costanza di marito ancor si vanta.
query.result:
**English:**
127 So much less is the plant than its seed, 128 as Constance still boasts of her husband, 129 more than Beatrice and Margaret.
**Cornish:**
127 Kemmys yw an plans vy dhe'y had, 128 vel, moy es Beatrice ha Margeret, 129 Costanza a wra gonis dhe'y gwreg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Vedete il re de la semplice vita 131 seder là solo, Arrigo d’Inghilterra: 132 questi ha ne’ rami suoi migliore uscita.
query.result:
**English:**
130 See the king of the simple life 131 sitting there alone, Henry of England: 132 he has a better outcome in his branches.
**Cornish:**
130 Gwel an myghtern a'n byw sodhel, 131 ow sedha yn unnik, Henry a'n Pow Sows: 132 ytho gwell effeyth y'n y gevynnow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Quel che più basso tra costor s’atterra, 134 guardando in suso, è Guiglielmo marchese, 135 per cui e Alessandria e la sua guerra
136 fa pianger Monferrato e Canavese».
query.result:
**English:**
133 He who is lowest among these, 134 looking up, is Marquis William, 135 because of whom Alessandria and its war
136 make Monferrato and Canavese weep.
**Cornish:**
133 An neb a wra moy isa y'n aga, 134 ow sel yn ughel, yw Markis Gwilym, 135 rag a wra Alessandria ha'y bresel
136 ow teves Monferrato ha Canavese».
